description: From Middle English mornen, mournen, from Old English murnan, from Proto-Germanic *murnaną. Cognate with French morne (“gloomy”).

entries.meaning: A ring fitted upon the head of a lance to prevent wounding an adversary in tilting.

verbs.description: mourn (third-person singular simple present mourns, present participle mourning, simple past and past participle mourned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To express sadness or sorrow for; to grieve over (especially a death).
examples: Abraham came to mourn for Sarah, and to weep for her.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To utter in a sorrowful manner.
